Spine Switches and IPN Connectivity 
If you have multiple spine switches in each pod, it is not mandatory to connect every spine 
that is deployed in a pod to the IPN devices, even though two should be a minimum for 
redundancy. For example, when you have four spine switches in a pod, you can connect 
only two to the IPN, without functional implications for unicast communication across sites. 
The local leaf nodes that encapsulate the traffic to a remote pod would always prefer the 
paths through the spine switches that are actively connected to the IPN devices (based on 
IS-IS routing metric). Similarly, you wonâ€™t experience issues with the BUM traffic that needs 


to be sent to remote pods, since only the spine nodes that are connected to the IPN 
devices will be responsible for handling such traffic.

questions.question_text: What two actions should be taken to deploy a new Cisco ACI Multi-Pod setup? (Choose two.)

An existing Cisco ACI Multi-Site setup with default fabric settings contains endpoints that communicate with an MTU of 1500. What is the minimum MTU value that must be supported by the ISN to allow control plane endpoint information exchange between sites?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I think the question here is a little bit tricky. Unlike the IPN, ISN requirement is just a basic IP connectivity among the sites. Which can be a generic IP network without jumbo frame support. To accommodate that kind of networks, they introduced a new policy which helps to reduce the default control plane packet MTU from 9000 to whatever is being supported. So the ACI is not dictating the minimum MTU but ISN is. 

My understanding is that this question is asking the minimum MTU that must be supported by ISN, and if the ISN is not supporting 9000, we can adjust the ACI fabric to match whatever is supported. I'd go with B.

The answer is A
The MTU of the ISN depends on 2 Factors:

1) The maximum MTU of the frames generated by the endpoints connected to the fabric: If the endpoints are instead configured with the default 1500-byte value, then the ISN MTU size can be reduced to 1550 bytes

2) The MTU of MP-BGP control-plane communication between spine nodes in different sites: By default, the spine nodes generate 9000-byte packets for exchanging endpoint routing information. If that default value is not modified, the ISN must support an MTU size of at least 9000 bytes

So assuming the Spines control-plane settings are left at default the answer is A : 9000
